bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, September 26, 1906

div1.p: Carroll will meet Latimer to discuss Kelly's book. Carroll offers corrections, and states that Lazear's work is not given due credit.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, September 26, 1906

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Sept. 26th 1906.

div1.p:
I
was very glad to receive
your letter of yesterday
this morning. I have
planned to visit Balti-
more on Saturday, and if
it will be agreeable to
you, I shall be glad to
drop in at any hour of
the forenoon or afternoon
and give you any information
in my power. I ran across
another letter of the same
series and I may find some
others that will interest
you. I have recently had
occasion to write a couple
of official letters bearing
upon the subject and I
shall bring copies of them
with me to show that I
do not hesitate to put
the facts on record at the
proper time.

The British Medical
Journal for Sept. 8" 1906
contains a couple of pars.
of great interest to me,
viz: the one at bottom of
first column on p. 546 and
the other in an editorial
headed “Sanitation in Panama.” p. 586. The
latter is quoted in Science for Sept. 21st.

Dr Donnally has called my attention
to the mis-spelling of his name on page
240. It should be: H. H. Donnally.

I notice an error of statement in the par.
at the foot of p. 133. wherein you state that
the experiment on me was followed by eleven others.
The nine negative experiments preceded
mine which was followed immediately
by one positive experiment only, at that time.

This is shown in the table on p. 10 of the first
paper. Cases 10 and 11 were the only positive
ones of this series. Please note that the tenth
case (myself) was bitten by one insect that had
been applied to a severe case, in the second
day of the disease, twelve days before. It had also
been applied to two mild cases, six and two
days previously, and to another severe case,
four days previously. I was bitten by this insect
August 27th. Four days later the same insect
was applied to case 11 with three other mosquitoes.
Add 4 days to the periods given in the 7th
column for the insect that bit case 10 and
AC
C to Dr
and you will be able to
identify it as the second
enumerated of the four applied
to case 11. on August 31st.
In the interval it had been
applied to another severe
case on Aug. 29th two days
before.

From this it is plain that
Lazear showed the true
scientific spirit for, on the
day that I was taken ill, he
immediately applied the same
insect, with three others, to a
soldier, who also was taken
ill within the usual period
of incubation. He thus im-
mediately proved the source
of infection in my case and
confirmed it at once by producing another
case with the same insect. For this he is not
given due credit.

On page 255, 3d line, the date of my
entry to the Army should by January 1874
instead of 1881 and on page 257 the
date of my return should be March 1901
instead of February.

I mention these points as they occur to me
now, and if you will kindly make note of
any points upon which you desire to
interrogate me, I shall be at your
service on Saturday.
